Notes: Place on bottom. Are voracious nocturnal predators, watch placement and distance between colonies

SPS. Pulsing or varying currents ideal. Several species of fish are known to consume or nip at polyps. Subject to infestation by Acro eating flatworms and Tegastes Acroporanus (Red Bugs). Acropora and Montipora corals make up one-third of all reef building coral species.
Does not like or need high levels of light
Agaricia is a protected coral and one cannot make legal collections of wild specimens. Place in lower to middle sections of the tank, depending on light intensity.

Common Names: Finger Leather/Colt/Seamans/Dead Mans Fingers/Encrusting Leather Coral
Notes: Most species are tropical but some are cold water and would require a chiller. Some species observed as photosynthetic only.

Place in lower to middle sections of the tank, depending on light intensity. May benefit from supplemental feeding with additional meaty and nutritious foods. Very delicate, most don’t survive in aquaria.
Polyps are visible throughout the day and night. Member of Euphyllia genus.
A group of colonial animals having several individual polyps attached to a piece of solid substrate. Easily damaged by predatory animals and stinging corals.
Rare coral rarely seen in aquarium trade

Solitary polyps. It is a non-photosynthetic LPS coral, needs to be target fed daily. Place on bottom or in cave like structures in tank. Tentacles only extend under no or very low light. Strong skimmer is recommended to take care of the nutrient load added by their required feeding.
Place on rock substrate where they do not get excessive light or water flow
A common name used to describe several genera and a multitude of species with varying needs. Please see individual species listings for information.
Will rapidly grow over adjacent rock work, coral, or aquarium glass
Has long sweeper tentacles and will sting corals in close proximity. Benefits from feeding when tentacles out at least weekly. Take care to prevent the bubbles from getting punctured by skeleton.

A round, solitary coral, usually having a single central oral opening. Handle with care so skeleton does not damage the soft flesh. Feeding several times a week with HUFA-fortified feed aids in growth and coloring.

Common Names: Kenya Tree/Taro Tree/Cauliflower Soft/Pineapple Tree Coral
Notes: May be disturbed by presence of hard corals. Invasive in that it will grow quickly, covering the substrate and everything in its path.

Place in lower to middle sections of the tank, depending on light intensity. May benefit from supplemental feeding with additional meaty and nutritious foods. Corals can produce sweeper tentacles at night capable of delivering a sting to neighboring corals.
Moderate to high light and water flow.

Common Names: Blue Xenia/Clove Polyps/White Pom Pom Coral/White Star or Pulse Coral
Notes: A colonial soft coral with multiple polyps extending from a mat. Grows rapidly and can overrun tank.
High light and water flow.
Handle with care so skeleton does not damage the soft flesh.
Needs excellent water quality and low nitrate levels. Sensitive to metal ions and requires the use of high-quality carbon.
Frequent feedings required
Needs to be fed multiple times a day with small food particles. They are slow growers, very difficult to maintain and not commonly kept in aquariums.
Feeds mainly at night and will consume meaty foods such as Mysis shrimp and small pieces of fish.
Polyps are visible throughout the day and night.
The species generally have large polyps and come in a variety of different colours, most commonly brown or green. Generally, found in both shallow and deeper water reef environments.

Common Names: Moon Coral/Brain Coral/Pineapple Coral/Closed Brain Coral
Notes: Needs moderate water movement and light. Tentacles come out only at night. Sweeper tentacles will sting other corals.
Also called 'closed brain coral' due to its similar appearance to the true brain corals in the family Mussidae.
Very aggressive coral, requires plenty of space between itself and other corals.
Needs moderate water movement and light.
Very delicate, most don’t survive in aquaria. Very aggressive, requires plenty of space between itself and other corals.
This coral is unique because it is blue, the only member of the family Helioporidae, and the only octocoral to produce a massive skeleton.
Most species are aggressive and need plenty of space between themselves and other corals. Sensitive to rapid changes in lighting.
Needs regular feeding with live phytoplankton, micro-plankton, and other similar foods.

Common Names: Lobed Brain Coral/Carpet Coral/Open Brain Coral
Notes: Needs moderate water movement and light.
Aggressive and has a sting that can be harmful to humans. Only recommended for experienced aquarists.
Multiple different morphologies
Needs moderate water movement and light.
Needs moderate water movement and light. Tentacles come out only at night. Sweeper tentacles will sting other corals.

Common Names: Tree Coral/Nepal Tree Coral/Spongodes or Cauliflower Coral
Notes: A group of colonial animals having several individual polyps attached to a piece of solid substrate.

Common Names: Green Star Polyp/Daisies/Mat/Clavularia/Starburst or Eight Tentacle
Notes: High light and water flow.

Benefits from feeding when tentacles out at least weekly. Take care to prevent the bubbles from getting punctured by skeleton.

Aggressive and needs plenty of space between itself and other corals. It is recommended to wear gloves when handling these corals.
Will eat most ornamental shrimp and fish. Do not mix with photosynthetic corals as it will overgrow and kill them.

Common Names: Non-photosynthetic gorgonian/Orange Gorgonian/Knobby or Spiny Bush/African or Orange Gorgonian
Notes: Needs to be fed multiple times a day with small food particles. They are slow growers, very difficult to maintain and not commonly kept in aquariums.
Can be very aggressive and may overgrow other corals. Generally harmless to other tank inhabitants.

Notes: Generally easy to keep, some species will release toxins that may irritate other tank inhabitants.
Needs excellent water quality and low nitrate levels. Sensitive to metal ions and requires the use of high-quality carbon.
